LETTER OF TRANSMJTTAL OFFICE OF STATE TAX COMMISSIONER LINCOLN, NEBRASKA December 22, 1941. Honorable Dwight Griswold, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln. My dear Governor: Herewith is transmitted the Twenty-first Annual Report of the State TaTcommissioner and the State Board of Equalization and Assessment for the year 1941. This report contains numerous state - ment™ supporting schedules listed in the Table of Contents, Pages 4 and 5- I wish to take this opportunity to express my appreciation for the co-operation of yourseli and the other members of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, also the fine co-operation and valuable help given by the Attorney General's office. I wish to express my thank! to county assessors, county clerks and other county offi - cials to whom it has been necessary to make frequent requests for advice and assistance. The following statement should be of interest as it shows the comparative assessed values for 1940 and 1941 revealing a marked increase in the Intangible "A" and "B». For *c first t™e the Con - sumers Public Power District is paying, m lieu of taxes, a fixed sum whTch, according to law, is the amount that was previously paid by private industries. 1941 TANGIBLE ASSESSMENT Below is given the assessment of tangible property for the year 1941 as returned by the several county assessors and equalized by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. Since 1921 property has been assessed at its fuil value, rather than one-fifth value, as was the case prior to that time. STATEMENT NO. 2 INTANGIBLE PROPERTY Property of this kind Is divided into two classes. "A" and "B". Class "A" Is all kinds of money and taxable at 2J. mills on the dollar. Class "B" Is all other kinds of intangible property and tnxable at 8 mills on the dollar. The assessment ot stock In banks, loan companies, trust and Investment companies Is included In Class "B". (H. B. 421, S. L. 1929.) Totnl amount of Class "A" »48.769,641 and Class "B" {84,476,449 returned for luxation fnr the year. STATEMENT NO- 5 ROLLING STOCK ASSESSMENT The rolling stock assessment of the various railroads is made by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment in accordance with Section 77-616, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929. The amount so found is divided by the total number of miles, giving +he total valuation per mile, and this amount is mu'tiplied by the number of miles in each city and/or village. This amount is then certified to the County Clerk to be added to the assessment of terminal property which is made by the local assessor and then equalized by the State Board. STATE OF NEBRASKA STATEMENTNO.II ¦;¦ STATE ESTATE TAX The state estate tax law, enacted in 1929, is administered by the State Tax Commissioner. The basis for the tax due is eighty per centum of the Federal Estate Tax less credit for any succession er inheritance taxes paid to any County Treasurer for a county or coun - ties in the Stete of Nebraska, but this does not apply to any tax paid another state. This tax applies only to estates of resident decedents, valued at $100,000 or more. STATE LOCAL 13.8% 86.2% From the above it will be noted that of every dollar paid in taxes by the average taxpayer, THIRTEEN AND 8/10 CENTS will be spent by the State and EIGHTY-SIX AND 2/10 CENTS will be spent Lo - cally. REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT NO. 17 MUNICIPAL TAX RATES 1941 The following report shows the population, assessed valuation, the various tax rates, and the total thereof, as well as the total taxes, in each of the 527 incorporated municipalities in Nebraska, and also the tax rate in 9 unincorporated towns, four of which are county seat towns. The total tax has been determined by applying the total tax rate to the valuation, rather than from the footings of the tax list. The data has been compiled from reports made by the County Clerks to the State Tax Commissioner. The following towns are in more than one county: Emerson is in three counties—Dakota, Dixon and Thurston. Ox - ford is in Harlan and Furnas; Tilden is in Antelope and Madison; Trumbull is in Adams and Clay and Wakefield is in Dixon and Wayne Counties. ?County Seat.
